title: Clarence Hale
text:
Clarence Hale (April 15, 1848 – April 9, 1934) was a <a href="United%20States%20federal%20judge">United States District Judge</a> of the <a href="United%20States%20District%20Court%20for%20the%20District%20of%20Maine">United States District Court for the District of Maine</a>.
Education and career.
Born in <a href="Turner%2C%20Maine">Turner</a>, <a href="Maine">Maine</a>, Hale received an <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">Artium Baccalaureus</a> degree from <a href="Bowdoin%20College">Bowdoin College</a> in 1869, an <a href="Master%20of%20Arts">Artium Magister</a> degree from the same institution, then <a href="read%20law">read law</a> to enter the bar in 1871. He was in private practice in <a href="Portland%2C%20Maine">Portland</a>, Maine from 1871 to 1902, also serving as city solicitor for Portland from 1879 to 1882, and as a member of the <a href="Maine%20House%20of%20Representatives">Maine House of Representatives</a> from 1883 to 1886.
Federal judicial service.
On May 13, 1902, Hale was nominated by President <a href="Theodore%20Roosevelt">Theodore Roosevelt</a> to a seat on the <a href="United%20States%20District%20Court%20for%20the%20District%20of%20Maine">United States District Court for the District of Maine</a> vacated by Judge <a href="Nathan%20Webb%20%28judge%29">Nathan Webb</a>. Hale was confirmed by the <a href="United%20States%20Senate">United States Senate</a> on May 19, 1902, and received his commission the same day. He assumed <a href="senior%20status">senior status</a> on January 1, 1922, serving in that capacity until his death on April 9, 1934, in Portland.
